text:
Dear Sir:

If you would send your questionnaires to Mrs. Herb Collins

605 Temperance St.

I think she would be willing and able to answer many more questions than I have as she was a little older than I and lived in the same district. Her husband (also an old timer although not in the West as long as her) died a short time ago and due to the upset she lost your first questionnaire. She was a Miss Hunter & the family were out here before 1885.

Mrs. Isabella Ross

Nov. 4/6 returned unanswered.

Eugenia:

This is Isabella Ross' mother, they are already answered, so don't include a sub. folder. You can type acknowledgment for Ruth Ross' 3rd or Letter acknowledging 2007. Thank you also for completing and returning questionnaires no. 1, 3 and 5.
Dear Sir,

If you would send your questionnaire &c.

9712 Hotel Ballin

605 Temperance St.

I thought she would be willing & able to answer many more questions than I have on the two or three little old timers and lived in the same district? Her husband (also an old timer although not in the West as long as he) died a short time ago & she & the widow she best know first question was she was a good hunter & the family was out here before 1885?

Mrs Isabella & Ross

Nov. 14th returned unanswered.

Regards,

[Stamp]
PIONEER DIET: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

(Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask., where it will be preserved as part of the permanent record of our province.)

Name Mrs. Isabella G. Ross.
Address 112 A.B. Ave. North, Saskatoon at present.
Birthplace Scotland.

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1909.
Where did you set up housekeeping? Elstow, Sask.
Where had you been living before that? France.
For how many people did you prepare meals? Three at first.
How far was it to your nearest store? Three and a half miles.
How often could a visit be made to the store? At Helen's, as we wished.
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? Flour, sugar, dried fruits, tea, canned fish, meat, rolled oats.

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Maddy Robin Hood.
In what quantities did you buy it? One hundred pounds.
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour?
How much did you use graham flour? One hundred pounds.
Whole wheat flour? One hundred pounds.
Was flour milled locally? Yes, how far away? .......... What year? .......
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats?
What other grain products did you use?
Cornmeal? Yes, Whole Wheat? No, Farina? No.
Other? .............................................................
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? Yes.
How did you grind it? ..................................................
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES INQUIRIES

PIONEER DIET: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to the Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask., where it will be preserved as part of the permanent records of our province.

Name: Isabella G. Ross
Address: 12103 8th Ave. North, Saskatoon, Sask.

Birthplace: Scotland

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1908
Where did you set up housekeeping? Saskatoon, Sask.
Where had you been living before that? England
For how many years did you prepare meals? 10 years
How far was it to your nearest store? 1 mile
How often could a visit be made to the store? Twice a month
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? Flour, sugar, dried fruits, tea, canned fish, meal, salt, etc.

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? National
In what quantities did you buy it? 50 pounds
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? 10 cents
How much did you use graham flour? 5 pounds
Whole wheat flour? 5 pounds
Was flour milled locally? Yes
How far away? 10 miles
What was the price for a twenty pound bag or rolled oats? 10 cents
What other grain products did you use? Oats
Cornmeal? No
Rice? No
Whole Wheat? No
Furman? No
Other? No
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? No
How did you grind it? With a hand mill
3. SUGARS AND SYRUPS

In what quantity did you buy white sugar? ...........................................
What was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar? .....................
What brand of golden corn syrup did you use? ..................................
What size of tin of syrup did you usually buy? ..................................
At what price? ......................................................................................

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? ......................
Butter? .............................................................................................
Eggs? .............................................................................................
What was the price of butter? ...........................................................
Did you pack eggs for winter? ...........................................................
Did you make butter? ..........................................................................
What kind of cheese? .........................................................................

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? ....................................
How did you get fresh meat? ................................................................
How often did you get fresh meat? .....................................................
How did you preserve meat? ................................................................
Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? ..................................
If so what year was it organized? .......................................................
Did you use game? ............................................................................
What part did fish play in the family diet? ...........................................
Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? ..................................................
Kinds? .............................................................................................
3. SUGAR AND SYRUP

In what quantity did you buy white sugar? _______ lb. at $______.

What was the price for a ton pound sack of white sugar? _______.

What brand of golden corn syrup did you use? _______.

What size of tin of syrup did you usually buy? _______.

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? _______.

Did you make butter? _______.

What kind of cheese? _______.

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? _______.

How did you get fresh meat? _______.

Was there a "meat ring" in your neighborhood? _______.

If so what year was it organized? _______.

Did you use game? _______.

For how long? _______.

What part did fish play in the family diet? _______.

Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? _______.
6. BEVERAGES

What kind of tea did you buy? Red Rose. At what price? .............
What kind of coffee did you buy? (beans or ground) Ground, but very little of it.
Price? .................. What other beverages were used? Lemonade, etc.

7. VEGETABLES AND DRIED FRUITS

What was the price of potatoes per bushel when you set up housekeeping? .......
........................ Could you get potatoes at the store? Sometimes.
If not, where from? At fresh from a neighbor & my father.
What year did you first grow your own supply for the winter of: 1909-10
Potatoes ...... Cabbage .......... Carrots ...... Onions .......
Turnips ...... Beets ..............
In what quantities did you buy white navy beans? 5 lbs. first year.
How did you buy prunes, (in bulk or by the box)? Box.
What weight? 10 lbs. How did the grocer handle prunes (by box)? Boxed.
........................ What was the price of prunes? ..................
What other dried fruits did you use in the earliest days? (apples, pears, apricots, peaches, loganberries, raisins, currants or others) Apples, apricots, peaches, some loganberries, raisins, currants.

8. PRESERVING

In the early years did you preserve any foods by drying? ....................
peas? No. corn? No. beans? No. Saskatoons? No.
other foods? No. ........................................................

What year did you first preserve fruit by canning? ....................
What year did you first preserve vegetables by canning? ....................
What year did you first preserve meat by canning? 1928.
Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying? I still can tomatoes, fruit, vegetables, & meat.
To what extent? Used 100 lbs. tomatoes, 100 lbs. onions, 100 lbs. carrots, 100 lbs. beans, 76 lbs. beef, 2 lbs. corn, 9 lbs. chicken.
Did you make your own vinegar? Yes.
6. Beverages

What kind of tea did you buy? Red Rose. At what price?

What kind of coffee did you buy? (beans or ground) Ground, but very little of it.

Price? 

What other beverages were used?

10. BAKING

What type of yeast did you use? ...Royal yeast cake... .....

Did you make yeast for your own use? ...No... Using starter? ...No...

Using hops? ...No.............. Salt rising? ...No..............

Did you buy baking powder? ...Yes........ Baking soda? ...Yes.........

Cream of tartar? ...Yes........ Did you make your own baking powder? No

What type of yeast did you use? ... Bread, cake, other... Using starter? ... No... Using hops? ... No... Salt rising? ... Yes... Did you buy baking powder? ... Yes... Did you make your own baking powder? ... No... Cream of tartar? ... Yes...

12. WATER SUPPLY

Where did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (well, river, slough, dugout) ..................................................................

How far was this water from your home? ...........................................

How was it brought to the home? (pail, barrel, tank) ...........................................

Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

Still use well, carry it when I am home.

12. WATER SUPPLY

Where did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (well, river, slough, dugout) ... well.

How far was this water from your home? (rail, barrel, tank) ... well.

How was it brought to the home? (pail, barrel, tank) ... well.

Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

Still use well, carry'd when I am home.
13. SOAPS

Did you buy laundry soap or make your own? ... bought some, made some.

If you made your own, did you use lye? ... yes ... wood ashes? ... no ...

What kinds of laundry soap did the grocer handle? ... Royal brown, I think, later several kinds.

14. FUEL

What fuel did you use in the earliest days? ... wood ...

Where did you get your fuel? ... the man handed it from his bush ...

Mention any changes in the use of fuels which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible. I still use wood & coal but most of my neighbors use oil for heat & electricity for cooking.

15. METHODS OF COOKING AND TYPES OF UTENSILS

For cooking, did you use an indoor fireplace or open hearth in the earliest days? (Give dates) ... no ...

Did you use an outdoor fireplace or bake oven? (Give dates) ... no ...

By whom was your first cook stove made? ... was called the house comfort ...

What year was it purchased? ... 1920-21 ... Price? ... $10.00 ...

What types of utensils did you use? (Iron, copper, tin, homemade) ... iron ...

For preparing food? (china, earthenware, wooden bowls, other) ... wood, then earthenware, tin, copper, other earthenware ...

When did you first see enamel ware?

Aluminum? ...
13. SOAPS

Did you buy laundry soap or make your own? If so, what kind?

If you made your own, did you use lye? If so, how much?

What kinds of laundry soap did the grocer handle? (Specify brand name)

14. FUEL

What fuel did you use in the earliest days? Mention any changes in the use of fuels which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

Where did you get your fuel? Mention any changes in the use of fuels which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

Mention any changes in the use of fuels which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

15. METHODS OF COOKING AND TYPES OF UTENSILS

For cooking, did you use an indoor fireplace or open hearth in the earliest days? (Give dates)

Did you use an outdoor fireplace or bake oven? (Give dates)

By whom was your first cook stove made? (Specify brand name)

What year was it purchased? (Give date)

What types of utensils did you use? (Iron, copper, tin, homemade)

For preparing food? (china, earthenware, wooden bowls, other)

When did you first see enamel ware?

Aluminum?
16. WRAPPINGS AND CONTAINERS

Mention any changes which you recall in the wrappings and containers received with the food you purchased (give dates where possible).

Most foods will sold in bulk measured & weighed by the storekeeper.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner and supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

In the earlier years oatmeal porridge + bread, butter with sometimes a little jam was the usual breakfast for the children + maybe an egg or some fried pork added for the men.

Dinner was often a pot of vegetable soup with bread or boiled meat with potatoes + any vegetable bread, butter + sometimes a pudding.

Supper was often fried potatoes, cold meat, bread, butter + some fruit or cake.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Western Canada? 1929.
Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at the time.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

As a child I remember us being very low on food quite often in the winter time as sometimes it was very hard to get to town but my mother was very good at making a meal out of very little. One time I remember us living on potatoes & white sauce for a few days.
16. WRAPPINGS AND CONTAINERS
Mention any changes which you recall in the wrappings and containers received with the food you purchased (give dates where possible).

Meal foods were sold in bulk measured & weighed by the storekeeper.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner and supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

In the earlier years we had a large garden plot for vegetables and fruit. We also raised chickens and kept bees. We had a cow and a pig. We often had fresh milk, eggs, butter, cheese, apples, and other fresh produce.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Western Canada? (Give date.)

Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at the time.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods?

As a child I remember we lived very hard to find food. We often went without meat as sometimes there was very little food. But my mother was very good at making a meal out of very little. One time I remember us living on potatoes while sick for a few days.
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

The food & the preparation were much plainer in the earlier days. Most women baked their own bread & cakes & there was not so many fancy foods then. Most of the food was cooked in the home.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homegrown and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

I don't.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandizing, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. (Use back of page if more space is needed).
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

The food in the pioneer days was much different from what we have today. Most women baked their own bread and cooked their own meals. There were no fancy foods then. Meat of the herd was used in the same way.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homegrown and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible.)

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. (Use back of page if more space is needed.)
